app.note: My scan is poor and it is not clear from Narasimhaswami's notation whether he supplies sya as illegible or as omitted in the original. I think I can recognise Ā after the vestiges belonging to ja, but if yu was quite narrow, then it is possible that sya was in fact also engraved. I also see no trace of r (nor of i) in the second character and believe that his r is a restoration rather than something he could discern in the plate. Assuming that I am correct about these, I prefer to emend and parse as above, but an autopsy may rule this out and confirm Narasimhaswami's reading.
Narasimhaswami notes that something was added below da and then struck out.
As Narasimhaswami notes, it seems that the marker for ū was accidentally added to tta, possibly instead of correcting stu to stū.

Narasimhaswami emends to praṇaptuḥ and in a note corrects the sense to naptuḥ, assuming the intent was to qualify Kīrtivarman as the grandson of Raṇarāga. Instead of emending the case ending and correcting the word to one with a different meaning, I prefer to assume that praṇaptāḥ was intended as a nominative qualifying Viṣṇuvardhana II, and meaning “remote descendant”.

Narasimhaswami corrects to -vijayasya. I believe the intent was rather -vijayatvād viṣamasiddheḥ (compare l4 of the Cīpurupalle plates and l8 of the Timmapuram plates), and wonder if a faint subscript v is perhaps actually present in the character read as tā.
The reading is clear even in my poor scan, but I wonder if something else had been intended by the composer, such as praśrita-, prārthi- or arthi-.

I accept Narasimhaswami's emendation for want of a better idea, but I am not sure this was the intent of the composer. There is also a pair of small dots, one below the other, on the right of kra above the headline, and another pair of fainter dots on the left of kra below the headline. These may be random damage, but it also seems possible that they are editorial marks.

The visarga is quite widely spaced on both sides, and there is a seemingly deliberate stroke between the visarga and the following ka, roughly oval with some additional strokes on the top, slightly resembling an archaic ma with very short arms. Possibly a jihvāmūlīya used in addition to the visarga and affixed to the left of ka instead of on top because this is the first line on the page, with a very narrow top margin.
Narasimhaswami's emendation is ingenuous and very plausible but may not be the only possible correction.

Narasimhaswami emends the nominatives to genitives and compounds lokāśraya to the following name. By my perception the composer had a more lax attitude to phrase/compound formation, which permitted these nominatives (among which he probably meant to include lokāśraya) to stand in apposition to the name in the genitive.Compare the other string of apparent nominatives in apposition to a genitive, starting in line 20.

Narasimhaswami also notes that what he reads as a final m was evidently intended for t. Though it looks rather like a small Brāhmī ma at headline height, I think it is in fact a final T, since this is not the usual form of final M in related records. I rather believe it is a reduced ta with a curled body, and what looks like the right arm of the ma-shape is either damage or, less likely, part of a headmark. Moreover, it was probably been added subsequently between tvā and the following rā, which may be part of the reason why it is not very clearly formed.

Narasimhaswami construes mahārājaḥ as the subject of ājñapayati (line 24) and emends the text accordingly. I prefer to assume that the adjectives in stem/nominative form were meant to be in apposition to the genitive, which in turn was used in place of an instrumental; compare the similar string starting in line 19 above. The visarga at the end of saṁpradattaḥ implies the end of a sentence here; the subject of the next sentence is in my perception to be understood to be the same king, but is not explicitly mentioned.
I accept the reading of Narasimhaswami, who marks the syllable ki as unclear.The consonant k is clear, and in my scanned estampage no trace of i is discernible.
The superfluous nā is faint and quite small; it may have been struck out in the original after the engraver decided that it was squeezed into too little space at the end of the line.
Could this be a scribal error for viṣṇu? Compare the list of donees commencing in line 34.
Since the vowel marker is attached to the headmark rather than to the repha, I assume that the repha was struck out (or meant to be struck out) in the original.
There is some damage around here, but from the scanned estampage, an e attached to the lower left of the body of the consonant seems quite certain.
The repha touches the descender of sya above and I assume that the vowel mark is present, but overlaps part of the subscript y. Narasimhaswami's omission of bhi is probably a typo.
As Narasimhaswami worked from the original plates, he may be correct in reading rddha here, but I see no trace of a repha here and prefer to assume that the r̥ was simply omitted.

On the basis of Narasimhaswami's translation I assume that his reading was viṁśottara-, and the omission of viṁ is a typo in his edition. This is plausible from the estampage, though daśottara- may also be possible. The actual number of shares apportioned seems to be 115 .

Narasimhaswami prints this word as clear. I accept his reading, but in fact nothing other than the anusvāra is discernible in the scan. Could this word have been corrected, like the one in the next line?

Narasimhaswami emends to Aṁśakāḥ and meticulously emends all numerals in the list of shares to masculine. While dvau does occur in the original several times in lines 38-39, I prefer to keep the endings as received.
Narasimhaswami also notes the fact of correction here, but does not venture to read the earlier text. Neither can I except to note that both vi and ti appear to have been engraved twice.

Narasimhaswami notes that these characters are written over an erasure. The first deleted character may have been vi (a mistakenly begun viṁśati?). A circle above that character is very conspicuous in the estampage. However, i mātrās elsewhere seem to be larger and more flattened than this circle, so this identification is far from certain. The original plate may rule this out, but from the estampage alone it also seems possible that pañca has been deleted and the circle is an editorial mark, with a correction intended to be written somewhere else.

Narasimhaswami only notes that two or three characters are effaced here, and that the character before the following bo has the vowel i attached. I think the last badly damaged character is probably ki though n with a subscript consonant (ndi?) may also be possible. It is probably preceded by two illegible characters.

Narasimhaswami notes that the final r is redundant. He does not explain whether he thinks so because the toponym is plausible without that r and implausible with it, or merely on the basis of intuition.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Face Ib. Fortune aux vainqueurs ! Que la réussite désirée de ceux qui accroissent la durée de vie, la bonne santé et la souveraineté du roi, de ceux qui accomplissent des sacrifices augmente sans cesse ! Résidant dans la capitale de l’illustre Asanapura, (Viṣṇuvardhana était) l’arrière arrière petit-fils de Raṇarāga, pareil à Saṁkrandana, qui fit s’élever la lignée des Calukya, méditant aux pieds de l’illustre et bienheureux seigneur Mahāsena, protégés par les mères des trois mondes, du même gotra que les descendants de Manu, fils de Hārītī, qui obtinrent leur royaume grâce à la faveur de l’excellente Kauśikī, dont la gloire s’étend jusqu’au cercle des quatre océans, qui pratiquèrent l’aśvamedha, Face IIa. l’arrière petit-fils de Kīrtivarman, à la vaillance insoutenable et à la gloire immense, (son grand-père était) le frère cadet aimé de Satyāśraya Pr̥thivī Vallabha, roi suprême des grands rois, excellent souverain, illustre seigneur, maître du cercle de la terre entière, soumise à ses trois pouvoirs. (Son grand-père était) le grand roi Viṣṇuvardhana, doué de vaillance parmi les hommes, grâce à une vaillance qui surpassait l’ensemble des hommes, qui posssédait tout le cercle des feudataires inclinés devant la lame de son épée, qui avait remporté des victoires sur des forteresses pourtant inaccessibles sur terre et sur mer1092, célébré comme le vache des désirs, que louent les hommes. Face IIb. (Son père était) le cher frère cadet de l’illustre grand roi Jayasiṁgha Vallabha, maître du cercle de tous les horizons, parfumés par le baume de la joie, engendrée par sa gloire, (elle-même) née de sa bonne conduite et des victoires qu(’il) remporta dans le choc de maints combats, dont l’esprit immaculé est aiguisé et fortifié par l’étude des différents traités, qui est orné d’une multitude de vertus qui sont la générosité, la noblesse, la dignité, la constance, la beauté, la connaissance, etc., dont les deux pieds de lotus sont rougis par les rayons lumineux des nombreuses pierres précieuses serties sur l’orbe des diadèmes des nombreux rois ennemis, inclinés devant la puissance de ses deux bras, refuge de tous les hommes, brillant par sa vaillance dans les trois mondes, dont la puissance n’a d’autre rivale que la moitié de Śakra, qui figure sur son héroïque bannière, dont la gloire est célébrée par la multitude des crânes de ses nombreux et excellents ennemis, Face IIIa. vache immortelle pleine de fruits variés et purs que l’on mange, nourriture faite de jouissances éternelles. (Son père était) le grand roi illustre Indravarman, possesseur de la vache des désirs, doué de connaissances expertes, obtenues grâce à ses trois pouvoirs, qui remporta le succès dans les batailles contre des cercles d’ennemis, car il était fin politique et possédait la vaillance d’un lion, refuge du monde et des rois. Face IIIb. Le grand roi Viṣṇuvardhana, qui mûrit de nombreuses connaissances acquises par l’étude des divers traités, ayant donné le village nommé Koṇeki dans le Paḷḷirāṣṭra, ordonne aux intendants du village et aux agents royaux1093, subordonnés1094, gouverneurs de province1095, intendants de rāṣṭra1096, messagers, troupes régulières, chef des danseurs1097, intendants1098, serviteurs, officiers subordonnés1099, chefs de département1100, juge1101, percepteur d’impôts, officiers en chef1102 : (nous) donnons au fils de Mahāsenaśarman, brahmane versé dans les Veda, dont la gloire s’étend au bout de tous les horizons, qui se plaît à sacrifier pour lui et pour autrui, à réciter et à enseigner, à donner et à recevoir, ainsi qu’à pratiquer l’ascèse, qui possède une exceptionnelle compréhension de tous les Veda, réputé sous le nom de « Vararuci du temps présent », Face IVa. à Viduśarman, qui connaît les Brahmaṇa, Sūtra, Mantra, Tantra, Upaniṣad, etc., et les nombreux Veda, du gotra de Parāśara, dont le cœur est plein de compassion et de bienveillance à l’égard de tous les êtres, de l’école de Taittirīya, qui suit les sūtra Apastamba, disciple de Kandeṟuboya1103, habitant à Ātukuru, au mois de Māgha, à l’occasion d’une éclipse de lune, pour l’accroisement de notre durée de vie, puissance, victoire, jouissance et souveraineté, à l’exception du terrain1104 du devabhoga. Face IVb. Puissent tous les seigneurs de la terre de notre époque et ceux à venir protéger ce village, ainsi que les officiers héréditaires en charge du village, Dhanañjaya et tous ses descendants et ses serviteurs nés dans la lignée de Ayyan ! Parmi les cent vingts parts de ce village, (nous en donnons) à Viṣṇuśarman1105, vingt, à son fils Mādiśarman, vingt, à Mahāsenaśarman, vingt et au frère aimé de celui-ci, à Dāmaśarman, vingt, Face Va. à Gaṇaiśarman, de Mudokuraboya, six, à Viṣṇuśarman, de Ātukuruboya, cinq, à Koṇḍasāmiboya, cinq, à Paṭiboya, un, à Mādiśarman, de Kumunūruboya, quatre, * * * -boya, deux, à Sarvaśarman, de Naḍukuṟboya, deux, à Peṭṭaśarman, de Veḷucaḷiboya, deux, à * * * -boya, deux, à Maṇḍaśarman, de Kanpaṟboya, deux, à Revaśarman, deux, à Irukuṭūruboyāya, deux, Celui qui transgresse notre édit commet un crime passible de la peine capitale. Face Vb. Il n’existe pas et n’existera pas de don égal à celui d’une terre, Il n’existe pas et n’existera pas de crime égal à celui de son vol. (1) Qu’elle soit donnée par lui ou par un autre, celui qui prend prend une terre se souille du crime du meurtrier de cent mille vaches. (2) Beaucoup ont donné une terre, beaucoup l’ont protégée, celui qui possède la terre en possède le fruit. (3) En la trentième année du règne auguste et victorieux de l’illustre grand roi Jayasiṁgha Vallabha, au mois d’Aśvayuja, le dixième jour de la quizaine claire, le jour où la lune est dans la constellation de Śravana. Cet édit a été gravé par Gaṁgavijaya et Vardhaki. Prospérité !
